text: [Music]
Um the lab is is sort of organized
chaos. There are about 35 or 40 people
in it, graduate students, um
post-docctoral fellows, technicians,
support staff, etc. Um we have probably
an unusually broad um research program.
uh we focus in three major areas. We
work on the biology of small RNAs. We
work on um cancer biology usually with
focus on the roles of small RNAs in
cancer and and ways in which we can use
smaller as a tool to understand cancer.
And then we have sort of a third area
which is um technology development and
genomics and mostly making use of some
new generation sequencing technologies
um to try to understand everything from
the evolution of cancer to human
evolution. Well, RNA interference
actually now describes a a fairly broad
range of biological phenomena. Um the
notion is that RNA has a sequence just
like DNA does and that sequence can be
used to recognize complimentary RNAs um
that share sort of the the inverse of
that sequence the mirror image of that
sequence if you want to think about it
that way and through that recognition uh
a lot of of jobs can be done. the RNA is
to recognize can be destroyed. They can
be taken to different places in the cell
or they can even guide um processes as
strange as uh taking pieces out of the
genome depending on what what organism
you're talking
about. So, one of the the sort of
evolutionarily deepest rooted roles of
RNAI is as a a genome defense. It's a
way that plants, for example, recognize
and fight viruses. It's a way that
animals recognize uh parasitic pieces of
DNA within their own genomes called
transposons and shut those off. It's
also a way that the cell um uses RNA to
program the regulation of its own genes.
And we can exploit any one of these
responses essentially tricking the RNAi
machinery into silencing any gene that
we want um just by fooling the machinery
into recognizing it as in essence one of
these foreign elements. And we can use
that for a number of purposes. The one
that we mainly use it for is for trying
to understand the biology of those
genes. Um and again in our case mostly
trying to understand um what different
sets of genes do in tumor
development. Well, we've done a number
of experiments in mice to to try to
figure out really what RNAi does in in
animals and I can give you a couple of
examples. So um one is we've looked at
the um small RNAs that the cell makes in
order to regulate its own genes and
compared um the spectrum of those small
RNAs in normal cells versus tumor cells.
In one of the first cases that we did
this was in a tumor type called bell
lymphoma. And by making that comparison,
we discovered that there were a set of
microRNAs which are what these um
endogenous um small RNA are called that
differed between the normal cells and
the tumor cells. And turns out that that
u the the locus the the gene which
encodes those micronas is often
amplified in that specific tumor type.
And if we reproduce that event, adding
extra copies of those microna genes, we
actually accelerate the development um
of that particular tumor in mice. The
another way that we approach this
problem is by taking um all of the
components of the RNAi machinery, all
the proteins that actually bind to the
set of small RNAs and that the smaller
program to do these regulatory events
and delete them from the genome and
essentially ask what the consequences
are. And it was in part those
experiments that led us to the
realization that RNAI in animals plays
this sort of genome defensive role
protecting um the DNA of germ cells from
the ravages of these mobile genetic
elements called transposons.
Well, for um a long time we've been
interested in using RNAI as a tool uh to
silence genes of interest, whatever
genes we want. Um and in fact, my lab
has built uh large collections of RNAI
inducing agents. In fact, collections
that could be used to turn off every
gene in the human and mouse genome. Now
the way that we use these to investigate
cancer biology is essentially to take a
set of cancer cells engineers engineer
them so that each cell has a different
gene turned off and then we ask how
those cells react under stress. What um
genes do cancer cells require that
normal cells don't? These are potential
targets u for therapy. What genes modify
the response of cancer cells to um
chemotherapeutic agents or targeted
therapies? What genes modify the ability
of cancer cells to engraft in a host to
metastasize etc.
Well, there there are really two ways um
that that one would move from the work
that we're doing into something that
would be applicable in the clinic. Um,
one is a a process that's being repeated
in many pharmaceutical companies, many
labs. Um, really built on the foundation
of understanding this basic piece of
biology, which is searching for unique
vulnerabilities in tumor cells. Now once
one finds a cell upon which a a
particular subtype of breast cancer for
example depends that the normal normal
normal mamary epithelial cells don't
depend on then one can find um targeted
agents standard ph using standard
pharmaceutical chemistry um that could
inhibit the activity of that particular
target and there you would have a
potentially selective therapy in the way
that things like gleevec um are
selective for specific gene
rearrangement upon which the tumor cells
carrying that rearrangement uniquely
depend. Another promise of RNAI is that
it can be used as a therapy itself. And
there is a tremendous interest in this
both in the academic and industrial
communities. the notion that um
pharmaceutical chemistry can only access
about 20% of the the genes encoded in
the genome because we have a limited
ability to regulate um chemically the
activity of the proteins encoded by the
other 80%. RNAI doesn't have such a
limitation. All it needs to be able to
do is to specifically recognize the the
sequence of that gene in order to shut
it off. And so it is essentially in some
ways a potentially universal um
pharmaceutical approach. The difficulty
is and I think this is where um many of
us are focusing a lot of effort is
trying to figure out how to take this
relatively large molecule compared to um
a normal pharmaceutical and get it
efficiently delivered to the cells um in
which the therapy needs to operate. And
so really that um is one of the major
barriers to taking this basic science
discovery and really exploiting it um as
a tool for improving human
health. Well, I I think that the way
this barrier to delivery will be
overcome is is chemistry. So I it's
clear that we've pushed the biology of
RNAI as a silencing tool sufficiently
far that given an ability to live to
deliver this, we could shut off any gene
that that we wanted to. And in fact, we
could probably
um dial the activity of these inhibitors
to the point that we could even figure
out exactly how far down we have to turn
a gene. Maybe you don't want to shut it
off because maybe it's essential. maybe
you you want to inhibit its activity 50%
or 80% and the tools our understanding
the biology is sufficient that we can
achieve that with the tools that we
have. Um I think that that where we'll
see advances in delivery come from is in
changing the chemistry of the um small
RNA itself sufficiently that um it can
pass uh through cell membranes without
the aid of a a specific delivery agent.
delivery agents are the other um sort of
arm of of research into RNAi delivery
encapsulating RNAs in lipids in
polymers. Um and that's another um
strategy for getting small RNAs into
cells. But my own feeling is that the
unformulated molecules probably have um
the best potential to be a future
therapy. It's a simpler formulation than
something that we know where you're
mixing an RNA agent uh and a series for
example of polymers to try to get them
across uh the
cell. Well, this this is I think an
interesting
um story about the social aspects of
science. In a way, the the realization
that that this transmissible cancer even
existed came from a graduate student in
my lab who um happened to be Tasmanian.
She did her PhD on um sort of basic
aspects of of RNAI biology. And when she
finished her degree before she moved on
to a position as a post-docctoral
fellow, um she was looking for a
transition project. And she explained to
me that this transmissible cancer
existed, that in the last 10 years it
had wiped out roughly half of the devil
population and that it was estimated to
actually drive the devils to extinction
sometime within the next 30 or so years
if nothing were to be done. So she was
very passionate about this and convinced
me that we had the tools to try to
understand at least something about the
biology of of this disease. Now, there
are only two transmissible cancers that
I that I know about where the cancer
itself, the cancer cells themselves um
move from one individual to another.
There's the this um Tasmanian devil
facial tumor and there's also a tumor
that does this in dogs. In dogs, the the
tumor isn't as aggressive. It often um
spontaneously goes into remission and
doesn't often kill the animals that are
in essence infected with this. In
Tasmanian devils, the tumor is extremely
aggressive, often kills um affected
animals in roughly six months with these
horrific um facial tumors that
ultimately kill the animal often because
they grow so large that the animal can
no longer eat. But it's a very
aggressive disease also in the sense
that it metastasizes
um to many sites in the body. But the
the the animals are killed so quickly
that that it's usually not the
metastases
um that cause them to succumb as um
happens in in many instances of human
cancer. So our our basic question was
really um to try to understand the
origins of this transmissible tumor to
try to understand what cell type uh the
tumor is derived from so that we could
maybe gain some insight into why this
tumor has such an unusual ideology and
also to try to understand why it is that
this tumor can spread from individual to
individual um you know as that's such an
unusual property. We came at it from a
number of different perspectives. First
really founded upon our work in small
RNAs. So um each cell type uh expresses
a specific repertoire of small RNAs that
it uses to regulate genes. But that
repertoire is also kind of a signature
of the cell type that um that those
small RNAs are expressed in. So you can
use a small RNA signature to tell uh a
mammary cell from a germ cell. You can
tell a nerve cell from a muscle cell.
And so we started off by asking what
spectrum of small RNAs these um devil
facial tumors expressed. And that
pointed us in addition to looking at the
messenger RNAs, this the RNAs that
encode the proteins within that cell by
looking at the small RNA profiles and
the messenger RNA profiles that really
led us to a specific cell type which in
this case um happens to be a Schwan
cell. Now what Schwan cells are is
essentially like the insulation on a
wire. um they wrap nerve cells and um
act essentially as an insulator to to
make their uh conductance of um signals
more efficient.
come out of that? Well, I I mean, I
think that the two things that that
really come out of the work that we've
done um looking both at the tumor and at
the host animals um are that the host
animals themselves are are remarkably
genetically
homogeneous. And so one I think insight
that emerged from the study was that the
the notion that the tumors may be able
to spread from animal to animal you know
essentially like a metastasis but within
a population rather than within an
organism. Um in part because the animals
can't recognize these cells as
foreign. Now in terms of a treatment um
it's difficult to envision wild animals
undergoing cancer therapy.
you you can't really um imagine a mobile
ICU in the Tasmanian bush. Um but but
one thing that that one can consider is
a prophylactic
therapy. And so cancer vaccines have
kind of a bad rap um in part because
they haven't worked particularly well
for humans.
But the the unusual nature of the
Tasmanian devil tumor. The fact that
every tumor is identical is a very
different situation than one was has
with human cancers where every cancer is
is different is is individual not only
to the person but in its genetic
composition. And so in some cases the
difficulties of developing cancer
vaccines in humans might be related to
the heterogeneity of tumors. whereas one
has precisely the opposite situation in
Tasmanian devils. So one can really
envision two approaches. One is the
approach that's being taken which is to
take an to take a set of devils and set
them aside as an insurance
population. And so you essentially
sequester um disease-free devils with
the idea that you know should the
population actually go extinct in the
wild you have um animals to reintroduce.
Now in that case we can use the work
that we've done um which in essence led
to a diagnostic um marker for this
disease to ensure that you know any
tumors that that insurance population
might develop aren't um
DFTD. In this second um instance, one
may imagine trying to develop a vaccine
against this particular unusual tumor
cell that could potentially be um used
on wild populations. Although again you
can imagine the challenges that that one
would face in doing that.
Well, so although each cancer is unique,
there are certain core pathways
um biological modules in essence that
are altered in nearly every cancer cell.
And the number of those modules expands
as one gets uh more specific to um a
particular subtype, let's say um
estrogen receptor positive breast
cancer. So the notion and this is one of
the ways in which I think RNAi is being
deployed very powerfully is to try to
correlate the vulnerabilities that are
created by the inactivation of those
individual biological modules and then
exploit that vulnerability for therapy.
The the the way that you can think about
this is that um cells are designed or
evolved to be
robust. And every time you take away one
of these these biological modules, these
pathways, it affects the robustness of
cells. Think about a Jenga tower, and
you're pulling blocks out of the Jenga
tower. The more blocks that you pull
out, the easier it is to make that tower
fall. And what people are doing with
RNAI is is trying to figure out
precisely what additional block to pull
out to make that tower fall where the
tower wouldn't fall if one had a normal
cell which essentially has homeostatic
mechanisms.
um to be robust to to resist the the
the biological difficulties that would
be created by the loss of the pathway
that would represent that key
therapeutic target. And so the idea is
to exploit common aspects of the
genetics to create therapies that that
overcome the individuality of the
disease.
Well, so although each cancer is unique,

are altered in nearly every cancer cell.

um to be robust to to resist the the
the biological difficulties that would

you know, it's um I came from a very
small town. Um I had very good and very
dedicated science teachers in high
school who um really went, you know, far
beyond the the call in a way um to make
um additional science training available
um after school hours, etc.
um doing things like um science
competitions that we know were held at
local colleges, things like this. Um and
even making available some very basic um
college science courses uh during our
later years of of high school. um going
on to
undergraduate um I went to Case Western
Reserve, a private university in
Cleveland with the idea that I was
probably going to do medicine. Um the
first semester I was there, I needed a
job and talked to my undergraduate
adviser who said, "Hey, why don't you
come work in my lab?" And it took about
a week to decide that, you know, that's
what I really wanted to do. And so, you
know, for me, and I think for many, the
the turning point um comes as an
undergraduate student when you become
exposed to um the world of scientific
research. It's, you know, not something
that a lot of people are intimately
familiar with. It's not a job that most
people see or encounter. And so I think
the key opportunity is to is to give
undergraduates the chance to come into
the lab to provide them, you know,
exposure to what a life um in academic
science is is really like. Um, graduate
education
um is something that at Cold Spring
Harbor we've um spent a lot of time
thinking about and and really Jim Watson
um pushed very hard about a decade ago
um to encourage us to fight against the
length of graduate training um which was
increasing to um what he felt were
ridiculous um time frames. And so, you
know, a 7-year PhD um of a a student
essentially not becoming an independent
scientist until, you know, well into
their 30s was something that he thought
um completely
inappropriate. And so, we've really
tried to to essentially
reinvent graduate education in a way
that allows um biologists to get a PhD
degree in um a short amount of time.
Four years is is our goal. we tend to
meet it. Um, by and large, I think over
the 10 years that our graduate program
has been running, um, our average is
about four years and three months. And
in fact, um, I graduated a student
yesterday in three and a half years. And
so, you know, the notion of bringing
people into research early and then
giving them an opportunity to um, do
independent work um, while they're, you
know, young and full of fire. um is I
think a really critical issue that the
community is trying to
address. Well, I mean we work for the
public. If you want to think about where
the funding comes for our research, it
it comes from the National Institutes of
Health, which is um supported by
taxpayers. And I think consequently, we
have a real obligation to communicate
science to the public. Um outreach I
think should happen at every level. I
think that working scientists should be
um interfacing with high schools for
example going into to high school
biology classrooms um communicating the
excitement of their work to students.
Um, Cold Spring Harbor Lab has a has a a
very strong community outreach program,
um, something they call the DNA learning
center, and it's designed to bring um,
middle school students, high school
students, um, into laboratories and and
expose them to laboratory science. I
think it's our obligation as scientists
to um, to reach out to the public in the
form of public lecture series. Um, we
also have a a strong public lecture
program at the laboratory. Um, I
participate in in it. I know that that
um many of the other investigators at
the lab participate in it. And I think
that that the public has to understand
science not only because they pay for
it, but because science is
um increasingly a part of their everyday
life. And to go back to the to the um
the discussion of sequencing and and
bioeththics, a time will come in the not
too distant future when you walk into a
doctor's office and they sequence at
least part of your
genome. And without a basic
understanding of biology,
um how is the how is the general public
going to react to this? How are they
going to understand um what's being
communicated to them uh about their risk
of disease and about how their own
genetics affect their response to
treatments? Well, I mean we work for the

of disease and about how their own
genetics affect their response to
treatments? Personally, to me, what's
exciting about research is the moment of
discovery. I think for most scientists,
it's what addicts you to this. the idea
that for just a few minutes you know
something that nobody else in the world
knows and it it it doesn't happen often
because science is is really sort of an
exercise in banging your head against
the wall over and over again. Um it is
scientists need a very high tolerance
for failure and frustration because most
experiments do fail. But when something
really works and you really learn
something fundamentally new
um it's a feeling that I think um I've
never experienced in any other way.
